column4: I'm having trouble getting a script to run on startup... I have put it in /etc/init.d and run sudo update-rc.d <script> defaults
I'm having trouble getting a script to run on startup... I have put it in /etc/init.d and run sudo update-rc.d <script> defaults
I'm having trouble getting a script to run on startup... I have put it in /etc/init.d and run sudo update-rc.d <script> defaults
how about upstart?
can you give me an example
what do you want the script to start, after startup?
sure
what is the command you want to run?
a script.... let's called it script.sh
place this in a /etc/init/some_file.conf          http://pastebin.com/qgQ7J96V
ok, and then ?
then the script will run at startup
I don't need to update-rc.d?
yeah, I wasn't trying to fix your problem, I was just telling you how I did it
what if the script has args? exec /path/script.sh start
will that work?
yeah, here is my original, args and all: http://pastebin.com/NCkVeqKQ
I will try that... thanks
that didn't work for me... I must be doing something wrong
I have a file called /etc/init.d/test.conf with your start on started tty1 and exec /path/file.sh start
hmmm, is the conf file +x, that might be it
the test.conf has 755 permissions -rwxr-xr-x
oh, and I think it is /etc/init/
ok I'll try that... thanks
